page.title: 02THE GROWTH OF WYKE
page.content: The textile industry also developed in the area during the Industrial Revolution and has remained to this day. However, with the recent slump in Britain's textile trade, its presence in the area has been greatly reduced. Benson and Turners spinning and dyeing complex in Wyke and a textile engineers at Low Moor, were the only factories we found in the area still engaged in the trade. The final stage in the area's development came with the large housing estates built mostly in the post Second World War period. Council estates were built at Woodside, Delph Hill, and behind St.Mary's Cgurch, Wyke. Private estates and old people's housing were built around Wyke Common. Recent building has appeared in Low Moor, Woodside and Wyke on re-developed and infil sites.
